Card1.title: Paper 1 - Multiple Choice
Card1.p: Questions are based on sections 1 and 2 of the subject content

Card2.title: Paper 2 - Fundamentals of Accounting
Card2.p: Questions are based on sections 1 and 2 of the subject content

Card3.title: Paper 3 - Financial Accounting
Card3.p: Questions are based on section 3 of the subject content; knowledge of material from the AS Level subject content is assumed

Card4.title: Paper 4 - Cost and Management Accounting
Card4.p: Questions are based on section 4 of the subject content; knowledge of material from the AS Level subject content is assumed

AS.title: Cambridge International AS Level students study the following topics:
AS.p:
Finaincial Accounting 
 Types of business entity 
 The accounting system 
 Accounting for non-current assets 
 Reconciliation and verification 
 Preparation of financial statements 
 Analysis and communication of 
 accounting information 
 Cost and Management Accounting 
 Costs and cost behaviour 
 Traditional costing methods

A.title: Cambridge International A Level students study all topics in AS and A level courses
A.p:
Financial Accounting 
 Preparation of financial statements 
 Regulatory and ethical considerations 
  Business acquisition and merger 
 Computerised accounting systems 
 Analysis and communication of accounting information 
 Cost and Management Accounting 
 Activity based costing (ABC) 
 Standard costing 
 Budgeting and budgetary control 
 Investment appraisal

Card1.title: Paper 1 - Multiple Choice
Card1.p: Questions are based on sections 1 and 2 of the subject content

Card2.title: Paper 2-AS Level Structured Questions
Card2.p: Questions are based on sections 1 and 2 of the subject content

Card3.title: Paper 3 - Advanced Practical Skills
Card3.p: Questions are based on section 3 of the subject content; knowledge of material from the AS Level subject content is assumed

Card4.title: Paper4 - A Level Structured Questions
Card4.p: Questions are based on section 4 of the subject content; knowledge of material from the AS Level subject content is assumed

Card5.title: Paper 5 - Planning, Analysis and Evaluation
Card5.p: Questions are based on section 4 of the subject content; knowledge of material from the AS Level subject content is assumed

AS.title: Candidates for Cambridge International AS Level Biology study the following topics:
AS.p:
Cell structure  
 Biological molecules  
 Enzymes  
 Cell membranes and transport  
 The mitotic cell cycle  
 Nucleic acids and protein  
 Transport in plants  
 Transport in mammals  
 Gas exchange  
 Infectious diseases  
 Immunity  
 AS Level candidates also study practical skills.

A.title: Candidates for Cambridge International A Level Biology study the AS topics and the following topics:
A.p:
Energy and respiration  
 Photosynthesis  
 Homeostasis  
 Control and coordination  
 Inheritance  
 Selection and evolution  
 Classification, biodiversity and conservation  
 Genetic technology  
 A Level candidates also study practical skills.

Card1.title: Paper 1 - Business Concepts
Card1.p: Questions are based on the AS Level subject content.

Card2.title: Paper 2 - Business Concepts 2
Card2.p: Questions are based on the AS Level subject content.

Card3.title: Paper3 - Business Decision-Making
Card3.p: Questions are based on the A Level subject content; knowledge of material from the AS Level subject content is assumed

Card4.title: Paper 4 - Business Strategy
Card4.p: Questions are based on the A Level subject content; knowledge of material from the AS Level subject content is assumed

AS.title: Candidates for Cambridge International AS Level study the AS Level topics.
AS.p:
Business and its environment 
 Human Resources Management 
 Marketing 
 Operations Management 
 Finance and Accounting

A.title: Candidates for Cambridge International A Level study all topics.
A.p:
Business and its environment 
 Human Resources Management 
 Marketing 
 Operations Management 
 Finance and Accounting

Card1.title: Paper 1 - Multiple Choice
Card1.p: Questions are based on the AS Level syllabus content.

Card2.title: Paper 2 - AS Level Structured Questions
Card2.p: Questions are based on the AS Level subject content.

Card3.title: Paper 3 - Advanced Practical Skills
Card3.p: Questions are based on the experimental skills in the Practical assessment section of the syllabus.

Card4.title: Paper 4 - A Level Structured Questions
Card4.p: Questions are based on the A Level syllabus content; knowledge of material from the AS Level syllabus content will be required.

Card5.title: Paper 5 - Planning, Analysis and Evaluation
Card5.p: Questions based on the experimental skills of planning, analysis and evaluation.

AS.title: Candidates for Cambridge International AS Level Chemistry study the following topics:
AS.p:
Physical Chemistry 
 Inorganic chemistry 
  Organic chemistry 
 Analysis

A.title: Candidates for Cambridge International A Level Chemistry study the AS topics and the following topics:
A.p:
Physical Chemistry 
 Inorganic chemistry 
  Organic chemistry 
 Analysis

Card1.title: Paper 1 - Theory Fundamentals
Card1.p: Paper 1 will assess sections 1 to 8 of the syllabus content. Written paper. Externally assessed.

Card2.title: Paper 2 Fundamental Problem - solving and Programming Skills
Card2.p: Paper 2 will assess sections 9 to 12 of the syllabus content. Candidates will need to write answers in pseudocode. Written paper. Externally assessed.

Card3.title: Paper 3 Advanced Theory
Card3.p: Paper 3 will assess sections 13 to 20 of the syllabus content. Written paper. Externally assessed.

Card4.title: Paper 4 Practical
Card4.p: Paper 4 will assess sections 19 to 20 of the syllabus content, except for low-level and declarative programming. Candidates will submit complete program code and evidence of testing. Candidates will be required to use either Java, VB.NET or Python programming languages. Externally assessed.

Card5.title: Paper 5 - Planning, Analysis and Evaluation
Card5.p: Questions based on the experimental skills of planning, analysis and evaluation.

AS.title: Candidiates for Cambridge International AS Level and A level study the following topics:
AS.p:
Information representation 
 Communication 
 Hardware 
 Processor Fundamentals 
 System Software 
 Security, privacy and data integrity 
 Ethics and Ownership 
 Databases 
 Algorithm Design and Problem-Solving 
 Data Types and structures 
 Programming 
 Software Development

A.title: Candidiates for Cambridge International AS Level and A level study the following topics:
A.p:
Data Representation 
 Communication and internet technologies 
 Hardware and Virtual Machines 
 System Software 
 Security 
 Artificial Intelligence (AI) 
 Computational thinking and problem solving 
 Further Programming

Card1.title: Paper 1
Card1.p: AS Level Multiple Choice. 30 multiple-choice questions. Questions are based on the AS Level subject content. Externally assessed

Card2.title: Paper 2
Card2.p: AS Level Data Response and Essays. Two essay questions and one response question. Questions are based on the AS Level subject content. Externally assessed

Card3.title: Paper 3
Card3.p: A Level Multiple Choice. 30 multiple-choice questions. Questions are based on the A Level subject content; knowledge of material from the AS Level subject content is assumed. Externally assessed

Card4.title: Paper 4
Card4.p: A Level Data Response and Essays. Two essay questions and one response question. Externally assessed.

AS.title: Candidiates for Cambridge International AS Level and A level study the following topics:
AS.p:
Basic economic ideas and resource allocation 
 The price system and the microeconomy 
 Government microeconomic intervention 
 The macroeconomy 
 Government macroeconomic intervention 
 International economic issues

A.title: Candidiates for Cambridge International AS Level and A level study the following topics:
A.p:
The price system and the microeconomy 
  Government microeconomic intervention 
 The macroeconomy 
 Government macroeconomic intervention 
 International economic issues

Card1.title: Paper 1
Card1.p: Reading. Candidates answer two compulsory questions: Question 1 in Section A, and Question 2 in Section B. Externally assessed

Card2.title: Paper 2
Card2.p: Writing. Candidates answer two questions: one compulsory question from Section A, and one question from a choice of three in Section B. Externally assessed

Card3.title: Paper 2
Card3.p: Language Analysis. Candidates answer two compulsory questions: Question 1 in Section A, and Question 2 in Section B. Externally assessed

Card4.title: Paper 2
Card4.p: Language Topics. Candidates answer two compulsory questions each on a separate topic area: Question 1 in Section A, and Question 2 in Section B. Externally assessed

AS.title: Candidiates for Cambridge International AS Level and A level study the following topics:
AS.p:
Sustaining accurate, fluent and consistent writing 
 Producing informed responses appropriate to the specified form, style, context, and audiences 
 Conveying knowledge and understanding from both specific examples and wider studies.  
 These are highly transferable skills and may help learners in other subject areas, as well as equipping them for higher education or employment.

A.title: Candidiates for Cambridge International AS Level and A level study the following topics:
A.p:
Sustaining accurate, fluent and consistent writing 
 Producing informed responses appropriate to the specified form, style, context, and audiences 
 Conveying knowledge and understanding from both specific examples and wider studies.  
 These are highly transferable skills and may help learners in other subject areas, as well as equipping them for higher education or employment.

Card1.title: Paper 1
Card1.p: Candidates answer two questions: one question from Section A: Drama and one question from Section B: Poetry. 50% of the AS Level, 25% of the A Level. Externally Assessed

Card2.title: Paper 2
Card2.p: Candidates answer two questions: one question from Section A: Shakespeare and one question from Section B: Drama. 25% of the A Level. Externally Assessed

Card3.title: Paper 2
Card3.p: Candidates answer two questions: one question from Section A: Prose and one question from Section B: Unseen. 50% of the AS Level, 25% of the A Level. Externally Assessed

Card4.title: Paper 2
Card4.p: Candidates answer two questions: one question from Section A: Pre-1900 Poetry and Prose, and one question from Section B: Post-1900 Poetry and Prose. 25% of the A Level. Externally Assessed

AS.title: Learners who follow the Cambridge International AS & A Level English Literature syllabus will develop the following skills and understanding:
AS.p:
enjoy the experience of reading literature 
 develop an appreciation of and an informed personal response to literature in English in a range of texts in 
 different forms, and from different periods and cultures 
 communicate effectively, accurately and appropriately in written form 
 develop the interdependent skills of reading, analysis and communication 
 analyse and evaluate the methods writers use in creating meaning and effects 
 encourage wider reading and an understanding of how it may contribute to personal development 
 build a firm foundation for further study of literature.

Card1.title: Paper 1 - Principles of Environmental Management
Card1.p: Section A: between four and six structured questions, with a range of task types. Section B: one essay from a choice of two questions. Externally assessed

Card2.title: Paper 2 - Management in Context
Card2.p: Between four and six structured questions, with a range of task types. Externally assessed.

AS.title: Candidates for Cambridge International AS Level Environmental Management study the following topics
AS.p:
Introduction to environmental management 
 Environmental research and data collection 
 Managing human population 
 Managing ecosystems and biodiversity 
 Managing resources 
 Managing water supplies 
 Managing the atmosphere 
 Managing climate change 
 AS Level candidates also study investigative skills.

Card1.title: Component 1: Speaking Test
Card1.p: There is no question paper for the Speaking Test.

Card2.title: Component 2: Reading and Writing
Card2.p: Two passages in French are set which deal with related themes. Candidates answer specific and general comprehension questions on the two passages, and respond to a task requiring a summary or comparison of issues raised. French will be used for all questions and answers.

Card3.title: Component 3: Essay
Card3.p: A list of five topics. The list changes every year. A question will be set on each of the five topics; candidates choose one question and write an essay in French.

Card4.title: Component 4: Texts
Card4.p: Candidates answer three questions in French. Each question must be on a different text, taken from a list provided. The list is divided into two sections: candidates must choose at least one text from each section.

AS.title: Candidiates for Cambridge International AS Level study the following topics:
AS.p:
Human relationships 
 Family 
 Generation gap 
 Young people 
 Patterns of daily life 
 Urban and rural life 
 The media 
 Food and drink 
 Law and order 
 Philosophy and belief 
 Health and fitness 
 Work and leisure 
 Equality of opportunity 
 Employment and unemployment 
 Sport 
 Travel and tourism 
 Education 
 Cultural life/heritage 
 Social and economic development 
 Scientific and medical advances 
 Technological innovation 
 Environment 
 Conservation 
 Pollution 
 Contemporary aspects of the country or countries where French is spoken.

Card1.title: Paper 1 - Core Physical Geography
Card1.p: Section A: Three data response questions. Section B: One structured question from a choice of three

Card2.title: Paper 2 - Core Human Geography
Card2.p: Section A: Three data response questions. Section B: One structured question from a choice of three

Card3.title: Paper 3 - Advanced Physical Geography Options
Card3.p: Candidates answer questions on two of the optional topics. Each topic consists of one structured question and a choice of essay questions

Card4.title: Paper 4 - Advanced Human Geography Options
Card4.p: Candidates answer questions on two of the optional topics. Each topic consists of one structured question and a choice of essay questions

AS.title: Candidates for Cambridge International AS Level Geography study the following topics:
AS.p:
Core Physical Geography 
 Hydrology and fluvial geomorphology 
 Atmosphere and weather 
 Rocks and weathering 
 Core Human Geography 
 Population Migration 
 Settlement 
 dynamics

A.title: Candidates for Cambridge International A Level Geography study the AS Level topics and two options from:
A.p:
Advanced Physical Geography Options 
 Tropical environments 
 Coastal environments 
 Hazardous environments 
 Hot arid and semi-arid environments 
 and two options from: Advanced Human Geography Options  
 Production, location and change 
 Environmental management 
 Global interdependence 
 Economic transition

Card1.title: Component 1: Speaking Test
Card1.time: 20 min - Presentation: No more than 3 ½ minutes
Card1.p: There is no question paper for the Speaking Test.

Card2.title: Component 2: Reading and Writing
Card2.p: Two passages in German are set which deal with related themes. Candidates answer specific and general comprehension questions on the two passages, and respond to a task requiring a summary or comparison of issues raised. German will be used for all questions and answers.

Card3.title: Component 3: Essay
Card3.p: A list of five topics provided. The list changes every year. A question will be set on each of the five topics corresponding to the year of examination; candidates choose one question and write an essay in German .

Card4.title: Component 4: Texts
Card4.p: Candidates answer three questions in German. Each question must be on a different text provided. The list for each year is divided into two sections: candidates must choose at least one text from each section.

AS.title: Candidates for Cambridge International AS Level study the following topics:
AS.p:
Culture  
 Health and well-being  
 Education and future plans  
 Community and society  
 Our responsibility for the planet  
 Science and technology

A.title: Candidiates for Cambridge International A Level study the following topics:
A.p:
Human relationships  
  Family  
  Generation gap  
  Young people  
 Patterns of daily life  
 Urban and rural life  
 The media  
  Food and drink  
  Law and order • 
 Philosophy and belief  
 Health and fitness  
 Work and leisure  
 Equality of opportunity  
 Employment and unemployment

Card1.title: Paper 1 - Document question
Card1.p: 1 Question. Candidates answer one two-part document question on one of the options given. Candidates must answer both parts of the question they choose. Externally assessed

Card2.title: Paper 2 - Outline study
Card2.p: 2 questions. Candidates answer two two-part questions from three on one of the options given. Candidates must answer both parts of the questions they choose. Externally assessed

Card3.title: Paper 3 - Interpretations question
Card3.p: 1 Question. Candidates answer one interpretations question on one of the options given in the syllabus. Externally assessed

Card4.title: Paper 4 - Depth study
Card4.p: 2 questions. Candidates answer two questions on their chosen depth study. Externally assessed

AS.title: Candidates for Cambridge International AS Level should study the AS Level content for Paper 1 and Paper 2.
AS.p:
European option: Modern Europe, 1750–1921 
 American option: The history of the USA, 1820–1941 
 International option: International history, 1870–1945

A.title: Candidates for Cambridge International A Level should study all the syllabus content.
A.p:
Topic 1: The origins of the First World War 
 Topic 2: The Holocaust 
 Topic 3: The origins and development of the Cold War 
 European option, Depth study 1: European history in the interwar years, 1919–41  
 American option, Depth study 2: The USA, 1944–92 
 International option, Depth study 3: International history, 1945–92

Card1.title: Paper 1 - Theory
Card1.p: Questions are based on sections 1–11 of the subject content. Candidates answer all questions on the paper. Externally assessed

Card2.title: Paper 2 - Pratical
Card2.p: The tasks in this practical paper test sections 8–11 of the subject content. Candidates apply knowledge and understanding from sections 1–7 of the subject content. All tasks are compulsory. Candidates select the most appropriate software and must use the most efficient methods to solve each task. Externally assessed

Card3.title: Paper 3 - Advanced Theory
Card3.p: Questions are based on sections 12–20 of the subject content. Sections 1–11 are assumed knowledge and understanding. Candidates answer all questions on the paper. Externally assessed

Card4.title: Paper 4 - Advanced Pratical
Card4.p: The tasks in this practical paper test sections 17–20 of the subject content. The paper includes tasks from sections 8–10 within a problem-solving context. Candidates apply knowledge and understanding of all subject content. All tasks are compulsory. Candidates select the most appropriate software and must use the most efficient methods to solve each task. Externally assessed

AS.title: Candidates for Cambridge International AS Level study the following topics:
AS.p:
Data processing and information  
 Hardware and software 
 Monitoring and control 
 Algorithms and flow charts  
 eSecurity 
 The digital divide 
 Expert systems 
 Spreadsheets 
 Modelling  
 Database and file concepts 
 Sound and video editing

A.title: Candidiates for Cambridge International A Level study the AS level topics and the following:
A.p:
IT in society 
 New and emerging technologies  
 Communications technology  
 Project management 
 System life cycle  
 Mail merge  
 Graphics creation  
 Animation  
 Programming for the web

Card1.title: Paper 1 - Pure Mathematics 1
Card1.p: 10 to 12 structured questions based on the Pure Mathematics 1 subject content. Written examination.Externally assessed

Card2.title: Paper 2 - Pure Mathematics 2
Card2.p: 6 to 8 structured questions based on the Pure Mathematics 2 subject content. Written examination. Externally assessed

Card3.title: Paper 3 - Pure Mathematics 3
Card3.p: 9 to 11 structured questions based on the Pure Mathematics 3 subject content. Written examination. Externally assessed

AS.title: Candidiates for Cambridge International AS Level and A level study the following topics:
AS.p:
Pure Mathematics 1  
 Pure Mathematics 2  
 Pure Mathematics 3  
 Mechanics  
 Probability & Statistics 1  
 Probability & Statistics 2

Card1.title: Paper 1 - Multiple Choice
Card1.p: 40 multiple-choice questions. Questions are based on the AS Level syllabus content. Externally assessed

Card2.title: Paper 2 - AS Level Structured Questions
Card2.p: Structured questions. Questions are based on the AS Level syllabus content. Externally assessed

Card3.title: Paper 3 - Advanced Practical Skills
Card3.p: Practical work and structured questions. Questions are based on the experimental skills in the Practical assessment section of the syllabus. The context of the questions may be outside the syllabus content. Externally assessed

Card4.title: Paper 4 - A Level Structured Questions
Card4.p: Structured questions. Questions are based on the A Level syllabus content; knowledge of material from the AS Level syllabus content will be required. Externally assessed

Card5.title: Paper 5 - Planning, Analysis and Evaluation
Card5.p: Candidates answer two compulsory questions. Questions are based on the experimental skills in the Practical assessment section of the syllabus. The context of the questions may be outside the syllabus content. Externally assessed

AS.title: Candidates for Cambridge International AS Level Physics study the following topics:
AS.p:
Physical quantities and units 
 Kinematics  
 Dynamics 
 Forces, density and pressure 
 Work, energy and power 
 Deformation of solids 
 Waves 
 Superposition 
 Electricity  
 D.C. circuits  
 Particle physics

A.title: Candidates for Cambridge International A Level Physics study the AS Level topics and the following topics:
A.p:
Motion in a circle  
 Gravitational fields  
 Temperature 
 Ideal gases  
 Thermodynamics  
 Oscillations 
 Electric fields 
 Capacitance  
 Magnetic fields  
 Alternating currents  
 Quantum physics  
 Nuclear physics 
 Medical physics  
 Astronomy and cosmology

Card1.title: Paper 1 Approaches, issues and debates
Card1.p: Candidates answer all questions. Short answer questions and an essay question, based on core studies. Candidates answer each question in the spaces provided on the question paper.

Card2.title: Paper 2 Research methods
Card2.p: Candidates answer all questions. Section A: Short answer questions, Section B: Scenario-based questions. Section C: A design-based question divided into two parts Candidates answer each question in the spaces provided on the question paper.

Card3.title: Paper 3 Specialist options: theory
Card3.p: Candidates answer two questions from two specialist options. Question 1: The question is divided into three parts. Question 2: Structured essay-based question divided into two parts.

Card4.title: Paper 4 Specialist options: application
Card4.p: Candidates answer questions from two specialist options. Section A: Candidates answer two questions from a choice of four. Section B: Candidates answer one design-based question from a choice of four. Section C: Candidates answer one essay question from a choice of four.

AS.title: Candidates for Cambridge International AS Level should study the AS Level content for Paper 1 and Paper 2.
AS.p:
Biological 
 Cognitive 
 Learning 
 Social 
 The issues and debates considered at AS Level are: 
 the application of psychology to everyday life 
 the use of children in psychological research 
 the use of animals in psychological research

A.title: Candidates for Cambridge International A Level should study all the syllabus content.
A.p:
Abnormality 
 Consumer behaviour 
 Health 
 Organisations 
 These include all the issues and debates introduced at A Level 
 cultural bias 
 reductionism (versus holism) 
 psychometrics 
 determinism (versus free-will) 
 longitudinal research.

Card1.title: Paper 1 - Socialisation, identity and methods of research
Card1.p: Candidates answer four questions. Section A: three compulsory questions. Section B: one essay from a choice of two. Externally assessed

Card2.title: Paper 2 - Family
Card2.p: Candidates answer four questions. Section A: three compulsory questions. Section B: one essay from a choice of two. Externally assessed

Card3.title: Paper 3 - Education
Card3.p: Candidates answer four compulsory questions. Question 4 is an essay. Externally assessed

Card4.title: Paper 4 Specialist options: application
Card4.p: Candidates answer two essay questions. Section A: Globalisation Section B: Media Section C: Religion. Each section has two essay questions. Externally assessed

AS.title: Candidiates for Cambridge International AS Level and A level study the following topics:
AS.p:
Socialisation, identity and methods of research 
 Methods of research 
 Theories of the family and social change 
 Family roles and changing relationships 
 Education and society 
 Education and inequality 
 Globalisation, Media and Religion 
 Contemporary issues 
 Ownership and control of the media 
 Media representation and effects 
 Religion and social order 
 The influence of religion
